page.title: List of Ramsar sites in Russia

revision.comment: sp, ce
revision.text:
'''Ramsar sites''' are natural locations under the protection of the [[Ramsar Convention]] for the conservation and sustainable utilization of [[wetlands]]. As of March 2013 there were 35 '''Ramsar sites in Russia,''' totalling an area of {{convert|10323767|ha|km2|disp=output only}}.{{cite web|title=Ramsar List|url=http://www.ramsar.org/pdf/sitelist.pdf|publisher=Ramsar.org|accessdate=31 March 2013}} The first Russian sites registered in the Ramsar Convention, on 11 October 1976 (during the [[Soviet era]]), were [[Kandalaksha Bay]] [[Lake Khanka]] and the [[Volga River]] [[river delta|delta]]. {{GeoGroup}} {{Clear}} ==List of Ramsar sites in Russia== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! style="background-color:{{RAMSAR color}}" width="15%" | Name ! style="background-color:{{RAMSAR color}}" class="unsortable" | Image ! style="background-color:{{RAMSAR color}}" width="10%" | Location ! style="background-color:{{RAMSAR color}}" width="8%" | Area (km2) ! style="background-color:{{RAMSAR color}}" width="10%" | Wetland Type(s) * ! style="background-color:{{RAMSAR color}}" class="unsortable" | Other Des. ! style="background-color:{{RAMSAR color}}" | Description |- | Area between the [[Pura River]] & [[Mokoritto River]] | {{CSS image crop |Image = Relief Map of Taymyrsky District.png |bSize = 150 |cWidth = 150 |cHeight = 130 |oTop = 30 |oLeft = }} | [[Taymyria]]
{{coord|72|32|N|85|30|E|region:RU_type:isle|name=Pura River}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/area-between-the-pura-mokoritto-rivers-ramsar-site-wetland-of-international-importance Borders (PP)] | {{val|11250|fmt=commas}} | Vt,Tp,O,Ts,M,N
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU697RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=Pura River Basin|url=http://www.birdlife.org/datazone/sitefactsheet.php?id=16531|publisher=Birdlife International|language=en|accessdate=June 3, 2016}} | Hilly plains with diverse network of streams, rivers and lakes distinguish this area from surrounding flat tundra in the central Russian Arctic, in [[Taymyr Autonomous Okrug]].{{cite web|title=Area Between the Pura and Mokoritto Rivers|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/697|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} Overlaps the [[Purinsky Zakaznik]]. Supports the vulnerable [[Branta ruficollis|Red-breasted Goose]]. [https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/278/pictures/RU697map1.pdf (RAMSAR map (pdf)] |- | [[Beryozovye Islands]] | [[File:Lake on Berezovye Islands.jpg|150px]] | [[Leningrad Oblast]]
{{coord|60|19|48|N|28|33|36|E|region:RU_type:isle|name=Beryozovye Islands}}
[http://www.birdlife.org/datazone/sitefactsheet.php?id=1526 Borders (IBA)] | {{val|120|fmt=commas}} | G,A,D
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU691RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Berezoviye islands of Vyborg Bay|url=http://www.birdlife.org/datazone/sitefactsheet.php?id=1526|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=6 June 2016}} | "Birch Islands", on the north coast of the Gulf of Finland of the Baltic Sea, on the southeast of Vyborg Bay. 300,000 to 500,000 birds migrate through in the spring - gulls, ducks, geese and swans. Indented shores with many inlets.{{cite web|title=Beryozovye Islands|url=http://www.ramsar.org/berezovye-islands-gulf-of-finland|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} Ramsar [[Ramsar Classification System for Wetland Type|wetland type]] classifications: G,A,D.[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU691RIS.pdf (PDF)] |- | [[Brekhovsky Islands]] | {{Superimpose2 | border = 1 | collapse = 1 | base = Yenisei Ob Kara Sea.jpg | base_width = 150px | base_style = float: right | base_alt = | base_caption = | base_link = | float = Red circle 50%.svg | float_width = 20px | float_alt = | float_caption = | t = | x = 50 | y = 20 }} | [[Taymyr Autonomous Okrug]]
{{coord|70|30|N|82|45|E|region:RU_type:isle|name=Brekhovsky Islands in the Yenisei delta}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/103550 Borders (PP)] | {{val|14000|fmt=commas}} | L,Ts,U,W,O,M
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU698RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Brekhovskiye islands|url=http://www.birdlife.org/datazone/sitefactsheet.php?id=16528|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=6 June 2016}} | Brekhovsky Islands in the Yenisei estuary; wetlands and tundra in northern [[Siberia]]. Habitat for whitefish ([[Coregonus]]) and the endangered [[Siberian sturgeon]] (Acipenser baerii).{{cite web|title=Brekhovsky Islands in the Yenisei estuary|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/698|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Chany Lake]] | [[File:Chany lake2.jpg|150px]] | [[Novosibirsk Oblast]]
{{coord|55|2|N|77|40|E|region:RU_type:isle|name=Chany Lakes}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95376 Borders (PP)] | {{val|3648|fmt=commas}} | Q,O,R,Tp,M
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU680RIS.pdf (PDF)] | | Chany Lake area is a network of [[Lacustrine plain]] wetlands characteristic of West Siberian forest-steppe. Enclosed fresh water systems, 100 km north of [[Kazakhstan]] border. Mire, meadows, reedbeds, forest-steppe floral communities.{{cite web|title=Chany|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/680|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Gorbita River]] Delta | | [[Taymyria]]
{{coord|73|00|00|N|94|55|00|E|region:RU|name=Gorbita River Delta}}
[http://www.birdlife.org/datazone/sitefactsheet.php?id=16524 Borders (IBA)] | {{val|750|fmt=commas}} | Vt,Tp,O,Ts,M,N
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU699RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Gorbita River|url=http://www.birdlife.org/datazone/sitefactsheet.php?id=16524|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=6 June 2016}} | Lower valley of the Gorbita River, and adjacent mire complex. Important breeding ground for geese on the Taymyr Peninsula.{{cite web|title=Gorbita River Delta|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/699|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | Islands in [[Ob River]] Estuary | | [[Yamalo-Nenetsia]]
{{coord|66|40|N|70|58|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Islands in Ob River}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95372 Borders (PP)] | {{val|1280|fmt=commas}} | F
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU676RIS.pdf (PDF)] | | Large floodplain islands where the Ob River opens to Ob Gulf; the Kara Sea is still 500 km to the north. 40% of the islands surfaces are covered with temporary bodies of water (sors). Breeding birds with a density of 500 to 2,000 birds per 10 km2. One of the world's richest habitats for whitefish.{{cite web|title=Islands in Ob River Estuary|url=http://www.ramsar.org/islands-in-ob-estuary-kara-sea|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | Islands in [[Onega Bay]], White Sea | [[File:Kiy-island Russia.jpg|150px]] | [[Karelia]]
{{coord|64|56|N|35|10|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Islands in Onega Bay}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95385 Borders (PP)] | {{val|36|fmt=commas}} | A,D,E,U,Xp
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU668RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=Onega Bay of the White Sea|url=http://www.birdlife.org/datazone/sitefactsheet.php?id=1523|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=29 September 2016}} | Kuzov Islands at the mouth of Onega Bay, the southernmost bay of the White Sea, 150 km west of Arkhangelsk. The islands are rocky and of glacial origin, covered in dward forests with stunted pine-birch communities, crowberry, moss and lichen. Supports rare plant and bird species, including the near-threatened [[Razorbill]] (Alca torda), and the [[Black guillemot]] (Cepphus grylle).{{cite web|title=Islands in Onega Bay|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/668|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Kama River|Kama]]-[[Bakaldino]] Mires | [[File:Kerzhenets river.jpg|150px]] | [[Nizhny Novgorod Oblast]]
{{coord|56|24|N|45|20|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Kama-Bakaldino Mires}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95387 Borders (PP)] | {{val|2265 |fmt=commas}} | U,Xp,O
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU670RIS.pdf (PDF)] | | Located just north of the Volga River as it flows east, 100 km east of [[Nizhny-Novgorod]]. The largest peatland south of the northern European taiga zone. Bogs, fens, raised mires, streams and other wetlands intermixed with stands of pine, birch, and aspen. Important stopover sight for migrating birds.{{cite web|title=Kama River - Bakaldino Mire|url=http://www.ramsar.org/kama-bakaldino-mires|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Kandalaksha Bay]] | [[File:Залив Белого Моря, утро.JPG|150px]] | [[Murmansk Oblast]]
{{coord|66|46|0|N|33|8|0|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Kandalaksha Bay}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/68148 Borders (PP)] | {{val|2080 |fmt=commas}} | A,B,G,D,H
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU697RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Kandalaksha Bay|url=http://www.birdlife.org/datazone/sitefactsheet.php?id=1520|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=29 September 2016}} | The northwestern bay of the [[White Sea]], Kandalaksha divides the [[Kola peninsula]] from [[Karelia]]. Over 850 rocky islands dot the shallow waters, whose rich benthic (sediment-dwelling) sealife support large flocks of migratory waterfowl. Much of the upper bay is protected by the [[Kandalaksha Nature Reserve]], which was formed in 1932 to protect the [[Merginae|Sea duck]].{{cite web|title=Kandalaksha Bay|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/110|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Karaginsky Island]] | [[File:Пролив Литке.JPG|150px]] | [[Kamchatka Krai]]
{{coord|58|47|N|163|52|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Karaginsky Island}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95381 Borders (PP)] | {{val|1936 |fmt=commas}} | A,D,F,G,E,M,O
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU694RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Karaginskiy Island |url=http://datazone.birdlife.org/site/factsheet/16487|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=March 29, 2018}} | Karaginsky is a 2,404 km2 island located 40 km east of the northeast coast of the [[Kamchatka peninsula]] in the western [[Bering Sea]]. The island is covered with elfin forests (stunted birch and dwarf pine), meadows, and low-bush alpine tundra. The numerous bays and inlets support large populations of diving ducks, gulls, terns, and cormorants; the island is on an important migration route for sea birds.{{cite web|title=Karaginsky Island|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/694|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Khingan Nature Reserve|Khingano-Arkharinskaya Lowland]] | [[File:Misha Sergei Lotus (6383858337).jpg|150px]] | [[Amur Oblast]]
{{coord|49|10|N|130|0|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Khingano}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/103552 Borders (PP)] | {{val|2000 |fmt=commas}} | Ts,Tp,O,M
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU684RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Akhara Lowlands|url=http://datazone.birdlife.org/site/factsheet/arkhara-lowlands-iba-russia-(asian)|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=March 29, 2018}} | A "wet forest-steppe" (prairie) ecosystem along the [[Amur River]] on the Russian/Chinese border in the [[Russian Far East]], between the [[Bureya River]] and the Khingan River. The landscape is an extensive floodplain, with streams, oxbow lakes, marshes, and other wetlands. Grass meadows and reed-beds are extensive, supporting aquatic wildlife that attracts migratory waterfowl (ducks, geese). A large portion is protected by the [[Khingan Nature Reserve]].{{cite web|title=Khingano|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/684|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Kuban River]] Delta: Akhtaro-Grivenskaya group of [[Liman (landform)|liman]]s | [[File:In Kuban Limans.jpg|150px]] | [[Krasnodar Krai]]
{{coord|44|50|N|38|30|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Kuban River Delta}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/103556 Borders (PP)] | {{val|846 |fmt=commas}} | F, O, Q, J, Ts, M, 6, 1, 3, 4, 2, 9.
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU675RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Kuban River Delta|url=http://datazone.birdlife.org/site/factsheet/delta-of-the-kuban-river-iba-russia-(european)|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=March 29, 2018}} | Extensive delta of the [[Kuban River]] and adjacent areas to the Protoka River, on the southeast coast of the [[Sea of Azov]] in the southwest of Russia. The land forms are bars and islands of fluvial sediments ([[Liman (landform)|limans]]) in brackish water. Because of the wide variety of wetland types (including freshwater, brackish, and saline areas), there is abundant aquatic life. This supports very large populations of migratory waterfowl (1 - 12 million per year), and large breeding colonies (500,000 individuals).{{cite web|title=Kuban River Delta|url=http://www.ramsar.org/kuban-delta-akhtaro-grivenskaya-group-of-limans|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Kurgalsky Peninsula]] | {{CSS image crop |Image = Кургальский полуостров.jpg |bSize = 150 |cWidth = 150 |cHeight = 150 |oTop = |oLeft = }} | [[Leningrad Oblast]]
{{coord|44|50|N|38|30|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Kurgalsky Peninsula}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95394 Borders (PP)] | {{val|650 |fmt=commas}} | A,U,O,E,D
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU690RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Kurgalsky Peninsula|url=http://datazone.birdlife.org/site/factsheet/kurgalski-peninsula-iba-russia-(european)|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=March 29, 2018}} | The Kurgalsky peninsula is located 125 km west of [[St. Petersburg]] on the south shore of the [[Gulf of Finland]]; it borders Estonia to the south. The site is surrounded by shallow waters, and covered with [[mire]]s (un-forested land with living peat-growing plants) and stands of [[pine]]. Kurgalsky hosts large populations of migratory birds, including [[Whooper swan]]s, [[Tundra swan|Bewick's swan]]s, and [[Greylag goose]].{{cite web|title=Kurgalsky Peninsula|url=http://www.ramsar.org/kurgalsky-peninsula|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Lake Bolon]] & the mouths of the [[Selgon River]] & [[Simmi River]]s | [[File:Берег озера Болонь ф4.JPG|150px]] | [[Khabarovsk Krai]]
{{coord|49|35|N|136|5|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Lake Bolon}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/103553 Borders (PP)] | {{val|538 |fmt=commas}} | O,L,Ts,U,Xp
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU697RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Bolon' lake|url=http://datazone.birdlife.org/site/factsheet/16561|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=March 29, 2018}} | Lake Bolon is a large, complex floodplain lake in the Lower [[Amur River]] region. It is fed by the Selgon and Simmi Rivers in the [[Khabarovosk Krai|Khabarovosk]] region of the [[Russian Far East]]. 80% of birds migrating through the Lower Amur region stop at Lake Bolon area, approximately 1 million per year. A wide variety of habitats are supported, including meadows, sedge and reedbeds, peat bogs, and birch forests. Rare fish are also supported.{{cite web|title=Lake Bolon|url=http://www.ramsar.org/lake-bolon-the-mouths-of-the-selgon-simmi-rivers|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Lake Khanka]] | [[File:KHANKA LAKE.jpg|150px]] | [[Primorsky Krai]]
{{coord|45|17|N|132|32|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Lake Khanka}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/68150 Borders (PP)] | {{val|3100 |fmt=commas}} | O,Tp,1-9,W,Xf
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/CN1155RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Khanka Plain|url=http://datazone.birdlife.org/site/factsheet/16548|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=March 29, 2018}} | Lake Khanka is the largest lake in the Lower [[Amur River]] region of the [[Russian Far East]]. The site is a cross-border area on the northeast border of [[China]]. On the Chinese side it is called "Xingkai Lake National Nature Reserve"; on the Russian side it is protected by the [[Khanka Nature Reserve]]. The area provides a stopover point for 1.5 - 2 million birds migrating each year between East Asia and the southeast to Australia. .{{cite web|title=Lake Khanka (Xingkai Lake)|url=http://www.ramsar.org/xingkai-lake-national-nature-reserve|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Lake Manych-Gudilo]] | [[File:Manych-Gudilo coastline (normal colours).jpg|150px]] | [[Kalmykia]] & [[Rostov Oblast]]
{{coord|45|42|N|42|50|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Lake Manych-Gudilo}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95390 Borders (PP)] | {{val|1126 |fmt=commas}} | Q
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU673RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Lake Manych-Gudilo|url=http://datazone.birdlife.org/site/factsheet/1487|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=March 29, 2018}} | Lake Manych-Gudilo is a connected series of shallow salt lakes with many islands, located in the flat depression between the [[Black Sea]] and the [[Caspian Sea]] about 200 km southeast of [[Rostov-on-Don]]. Situation among black-earth grasslands, the zooplankton and benthic aquatic life are abundant, supporting an important staging area for migrating birds, particularly geese and shorebirds. Much of the site is protected by the federal [[Chornye-Zemli Nature Reserve]].{{cite web|title=Lake Manych-Gudilo|url=http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=RUS+15&mode=all|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=UNESCO MAB Directory|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Lake Udyl]] & the mouths of the [[Bichi River|Bichi]] [[Bitki River|Bitki]] & [[Pilda River|Pilda]] Rivers | {{Superimpose2 | border = 1 | collapse = 1 | base = Amur to Sea.png | base_width = 150px | base_style = float: right | base_alt = | base_caption = | base_link = | float = Red circle 50%.svg | float_width = 23px | float_alt = | float_caption = | t = | x = 82 | y = 78 }} | [[Khabarovsk Krai]]
{{coord|52|9|N|139|51|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Lake Udyl}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/103554 Borders (PP)] | {{val|576 |fmt=commas}} | O,L,Ts,U,Xp
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU687RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Udyl' Lake|url=http://datazone.birdlife.org/site/factsheet/16567|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=March 29, 2018}} | Lake Udyl is a 330 km2 freshwater lake, 200 km upstream from the mouth of the [[Amur River]] on the Sea of Okhotsk in the [[Russian Far East]]. The lake is shallow (2–3 meters in summer), with adjacent wet meadows and mires. It supports the largest population of the [[Swan goose]] and [[Stellar's Sea Eagle]] in the Amur region.{{cite web|title=Lake Udyl|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/687|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Lower Dvuobje]] | | [[Khanty–Mansi]] & [[Yamalo-Nenetsia]]
{{coord|64|32|N|65|46|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Dvuobje}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95373 Borders (PP)] | {{val|5400 |fmt=commas}} | Ts,P,O,W,Tp,M
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU677RIS.pdf (PDF)] | | Located on the Ob River floodplain, the largest floodplain in northern Eurasia, 100 km south of where the Ob opens into the Ob Gulf. The Ramsar site is split into three sectors to cover the mouths of tributary rivers. The extensive wetlands are an important breeding and molting ground for ducks and swans, and is an important feeding ground for sturgeon and whitefish.{{cite web|title=Lower Dvuobje|url=http://www.ramsar.org/lower-dvuobje|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Moroshechnaya River]] | | [[Kamchatka Krai]]
{{coord|56|21|N|156|15|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Moroshechnaya}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95382 Borders (PP)] | {{val|2190 |fmt=commas}} | U,J,O,Tp,W,M
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU695RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Moroshechaya|url=http://datazone.birdlife.org/site/factsheet/16481|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=March 29, 2018}} | Located on the west-central coast of the [[Kamchatka peninsula]]. The site covers the Moroshechnaya River valley, with many oxbow lakes and a saline lagoon on the [[Okhotsk Sea]]. The terrain is peat soil on loose Neogene rocks. Among the many breeding and molting birds is the largest population of the [[Bean goose]] (Anser fabalis).{{cite web|title=Moroshechnaya River|url=http://www.mpatlas.org/mpa/sites/2552/|website=MPAAtlas|publisher=MPAAtlas|accessdate=4 June 2016}}{{cite web|title=Moroshechnaya|url=http://www.ramsar.org/moroshechnaya-river|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Mshinskaya Wetland]] system | [[File:Болото с сосной и багульником.jpg|150px]] | [[Leningrad Oblast]]
{{coord|59|3|0|N|30|13|0|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Mshinskaya Wetland}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95396 Borders (PP)] | {{val|751 |fmt=commas}} | U,Xp,O,M
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU692RIS.pdf (PDF)] | | A bird sanctuary. Rare species of birds include [[osprey]], [[golden eagle]], [[white stork]], [[black stork]], [[black-throated loon]], [[whooper swan]], [[Eurasian curlew]], [[Eurasian eagle-owl]], and [[Eurasian bittern]].{{cite web|title=Mshinskaya Wetland System|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/692|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Oka River]] & [[Pra River (Russia)|Pra River]] floodplains | [[File:Река Пра у Брыкина Бора.jpg|150px]] | [[Ryazan Oblast]]
{{coord|55|31|N|40|33|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Oka - Pra River}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95388 Borders (PP)] | {{val|1615|fmt=commas}} | M, Ts, O, Xp, U
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU671RIS.pdf (PDF)] | | Lowland rivers, oxbow lakes, and forested peatlands 120 km east of [[Moscow]] in the [[Ryazan]] region. Covering part of the area known as the Meshcora lowlands, the site features extensive fens in the center of the area, peatlands in the northwest, and meadows to the east. Over 70 species of aquatic plants are found within the borders. 50% of the [[White-fronted goose]] population uses the site during migration.{{cite web|title=Oka River and Pra River Floodplains|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/671|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Parapolsky Dol]] | | [[Kamchatka Krai]]
{{coord|61|37|N|165|47|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Parapolsky Dol}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95380 Borders (PP)] | {{val|12000 |fmt=commas}} | Vt,O,P,U,Tp,M
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU693RIS.pdf (PDF)] | | Located on the main migratory bird flyway from South-East Asia to Chukotka and Yakutia regions.{{cite web|title=Parapolsky Dol|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/693|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Pskovsko-Chudskaya Lowland]] | [[File:Tolba.jpg|150px]] | [[Pskov Oblast]]
{{coord|58|9|N|27|52|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Pskovsko-Chudskaya Lowland}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95386 Borders (PP)] | {{val|936 |fmt=commas}} | O, L, Ts, Xp, U, M
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU669RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Chudsko-Pskovski Lake and the adjacent areas|url=http://datazone.birdlife.org/site/factsheet/1529|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=March 29, 2018}} | Covers as series of freshwater lakes along lakes Chudskoye, Teploye and Pskovskoye on the border between [[Russia]] and [[Estonia]], 7 km northwest of the city of [[Pskov]]. Aside from its importance as a stopover site for migratory birds, the site plays a key role in filtering groundwater and protecting freshwater fish. Of the 277 species of birds recorded, over 200 are breeding, including significant populations of [[Great crested grebe]] and [[Eurasian coot]].{{cite web|title=Pskovsko-Chudskaya Lowland|url=http://www.ramsar.org/pskovsko-chudskaya-lowland|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Selenga]] Delta | [[File:SelengaDelta.JPG|150px]] | [[Republic of Buryatia|Buryatia]]
{{coord|52|17|N|106|22|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Selenga Delta}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95378 Borders (PP)] | {{val|121 |fmt=commas}} | L
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU682RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Selenga Delta|url=http://datazone.birdlife.org/site/factsheet/16455|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=March 29, 2018}} | The [[Selenga River]] enters [[Lake Baikal]] from the east, forming a delta that is about 85% regularly flooded meadows. The delta, the largest in the Baikal catchment, is a critical nesting site for waterfowl. The delta also filters the river water before it enters the lake itself. The RAMSAR site borders cover about 25% of the overall delta, and is protected by the Kabansky Nature Reserve. {{cite web|title=Selenga Delta|url=http://www.ramsar.org/selenga-delta|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | Southern coast of the [[Gulf of Finland]] | [[File:Map Gulf of Finland-en.svg|150px]] | [[Leningrad Oblast]]
{{coord|60|0|N|29|15|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Southern coast Gulf of Finland}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95393 Borders (PP)] | {{val|64 |fmt=commas}} | A,E,G
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU689RIS.pdf (PDF)] | | The RAMSAR site on the south side of the bridge over the Gulf of Finland to [[Kotlin Island]]. The small, shallow bay of reed beds [[Phragmites]] and sandy beaches is an important staging ground for the spring migration of waterfowl, and to a lesser extent the fall migration. One 10 km2 area has recorded 25,000 swans and 100,000 diving ducks. 17 species from the area are listed in the Red Book of vulnerable species in the area, including the [[Smew]]{{cite web|title=Southern coast of the Gulf of Finland|url=http://www.ramsar.org/southern-coast-of-the-gulf-of-finland-baltic-sea|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Svir River]] Delta | [[File:Sviritsa. Свирица. - panoramio.jpg|150px]] | [[Leningrad Oblast]]
{{coord|60|35|N|32|56|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Svir River Delta}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95392 Borders (PP)] | {{val|605 |fmt=commas}} | L,U,Ts,Tp,O,M
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU688RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Mouth of the Svir River|url=http://datazone.birdlife.org/site/factsheet/1524|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=March 29, 2018}} | The Svir River enters [[Lake Ladoga]] on the east side, through a delta of channels, lakes, marshes, wet meadows and [[polder]]. The RAMSAR site includes 6,500 ha of the shallow water area of Lake Ladoga. The site is an important staging breeding ground for migratory birds. Counts of migrating geese have been found at 150,000, and 600,000 ducks.{{cite web|title=Svir River Delta|url=http://www.ramsar.org/svir-delta|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Tobol River|Tobol]]-[[Ishim River|Ishim]] Forest-steppe | [[File:Reka Ishim Petropavlovskij gidrouzel.jpg|150px]] | [[Tyumen Oblast]]
{{coord|55|27|N|69|0|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Tobol-Ishim Forest-steppe}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95375 Borders (PP)] | {{val|12170 |fmt=commas}} | Q,O,R,P,N
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU679RIS.pdf (PDF)] | | The Tobol-Isham site is a flat (around 100 meters above sea level) forest-steppe region of lakes and marshy depressions in the south of the [[West Siberian Plain]]. The landscape is one of willow and birch forests, supporting woodland animals, and bogs in the north, sedges in the middle, and grass-reed communities in the south. The area is on a major migration route for birds, between West Siberia and wintering grounds from western Europe to southwestern Asia.{{cite web|title=Tobol-Ishim Forest-steppe|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/679|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Daursky Nature Reserve|Torey Lakes]] | [[File:Торейские озера.JPG|150px]] | [[Chita Oblast]]
{{coord|50|05|N|115|32|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Torey Lakes}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95379 Borders (PP)] | {{val|1725 |fmt=commas}} | Q,R,Ss,Ts,P,M
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU683RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Torey Lakes|url=http://datazone.birdlife.org/site/factsheet/16583|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=March 29, 2018}} | Located on the border between Russia and Mongolia, Torry Lakes is a system of soda lakes in the steppe region southeast of [[Lake Baikal]]. The biodiversity of the site is very high because it is a meeting zone of many fauna communities: taiga, tundra, broad-leaved forests, and steppe. Over 305 bird species have been recorded, including 90 breeding species. Much of the site is protected by the [[Daursky Nature Reserve]].{{cite web|title=Torey Lakes|url=http://www.ramsar.org/torey-lakes|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Upper Dvuobje]] | | [[Khanty–Mansi]]
{{coord|64|32|N|65|46|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Upper Dvuobje}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95374 Borders (PP)] | {{val|4700 |fmt=commas}} | P,Ts,Tp,O,M
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU678RIS.pdf (PDF)] | | The Upper Dvuobje site is a network of floodplain tributaries of the [[Ob River]] on the [[West Siberian Plain]]. The site features meandering river channels, permanent and seasonal lakes, forested islands, and meadows. Because of the wide variety of habitats interacting with each other, the terrestrial and aquatic life is diverse. Migrating birds number 500,000 to 3 million each year, and 300,000 are estimated to breed on the site.{{cite web|title=Upper Dvuobje|url=http://www.ramsar.org/upper-dvuobje|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Utkholok]] | | [[Kamchatka Krai]]
{{coord|57|40|N|157|11|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Utkholok}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/utkholok-ramsar-site-wetland-of-international-importance Borders (PP)] | {{val|2200 |fmt=commas}} | U,L,O,M
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU696RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Utkholok River|url=http://datazone.birdlife.org/site/factsheet/16484|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=March 29, 2018}} | The Utkholok site is located on the west coast of the [[Kamchatka peninsula]], on and surrounding Cape Cape Utkholoksky, which juts out into the [[Sea of Okhotsk]], and the wetlands of the Utkholok River and Kvachina River. With extensive tundra wetlands (mostly [[Empetrum|Crowberry]] and [[Carex|sedges]]) and bogs, the area is important to migrating and breeding birds, particularly the [[Bean Goose]] (Anser fabalis). The rivers are important spawning grounds for [[Golden trout]].{{cite web|title=Utkholok|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/696|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Veselovskoye Reservoir]] | | [[Rostov Oblast]]
{{coord|46|55|N|41|02|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Veselovskoye Reservoir}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95389 Borders (PP)] | {{val|3090 |fmt=commas}} | O, 3, 1
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU672RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Veselovskoye Reservoir|url=http://datazone.birdlife.org/site/factsheet/1427|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=March 29, 2018}} | A chain of lakes and reservoirs, about 75 km southeast of [[Rostov-on-Don]] in the flat plain of the [[Manych River]] valley between the [[Black Sea]] and [[Caspian Sea]]. Terrain is many small islands, shallow bays. The site is an important staging, breeding, and moulting ground for waterfowl, particularly geese and is also important for wintering birds.{{cite web|title=Veselovskoye Reservoir|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/672|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Volga River]] Delta | [[File:Astrachan Volgadelta.jpg|150px]] | [[Astrakhan Oblast]]
{{coord|45|54|N|48|47|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Volga River Delta}}
[ Borders (PP)] | {{val|8000 |fmt=commas}} | L,Q
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU111RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Volga Delta|url=http://datazone.birdlife.org/site/factsheet/1495|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=March 29, 2018}} | The delta of the [[Volga River]] as it enters the [[Caspian Sea]] from the northwest, is the largest inland river delta in Europe. The terrain is a network of riverine floodplains, and islands. The site features rich biodiversity in both fish and birds. A portion of the delta is protected by the [[Astrakhan Nature Reserve]].{{cite web|title=Volga River]] Delta|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/111|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | Wetlands in the Lower [[Bagansky District]] area | [[File:Озеро "Горькое" с берега в обработке.jpg|150px]] | [[Novosibirsk Oblast]]
{{coord|54|9|N|78|23|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Lower Bagan}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/95377 Borders (PP)] | {{val|269 |fmt=commas}} | Q,R,P,N
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU681RIS.pdf (PDF)] | IBA{{cite web|title=IBA: Baganskiye Lakes|url=http://datazone.birdlife.org/site/factsheet/29687|website=Birdlife Data Zone|publisher=Birdlife International|accessdate=March 29, 2018}} | Located in an herb and feather-grass steppe zone, the lower Bagan River features many small lakes with varying levels of salinity and permanence. Vegetation includes halophytic (salt-tolerant) species, reed-beds, and meadows. Water levels vary from year to year, and the importance of the site also varies for migrating and breeding birds as it is an alternative when the Chany Lakes site (50 km to the north) experiences a dry year.{{cite web|title=Lower Bagan|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/681|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |- | [[Zeya River|Zeya]]-[[Bureya River|Bureya]] Plains | | [[Amur Oblast]]
{{coord|49|55|N|127|39|E|region:RU_type:waterbody|name=Zeya-Bureya Plains}}
[http://www.protectedplanet.net/103558 Borders (PP)] | {{val|316 |fmt=commas}} | Ts,O,M
[https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/RU685RIS.pdf (PDF)] | | Floodplains of the Zeya River and Bureya River, 20 km south of [[Blagoveshchensk]] in the Amur valley of [[Amur Oblast]]. 5–10 km wide, the site features islands and beaches in the lower reaches, and marshes and oxbow lakes on the higher terraces. The site is important for migrating and breeding birds. The temperatures in the area are the highest in the [[Russian Far East]], with mean temperatures over {{convert|20|C|F}}.{{cite web|title=Zeya-Bureya Plains|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/685|website=RAMSAR Sites Information Service|publisher=RAMSAR Programme|accessdate=4 June 2016}} |} ==Classification codes for RAMSAR Wetland Types== * [[Ramsar Classification System for Wetland Type|Ramsar classification codes]] are listed for each site in descending order of area cover at the site. {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} '''Marine / Coastal Wetlands''' * A — Permanent shallow marine waters. * B — Marine subtidal aquatic beds. * C — Coral reefs. * D — Rocky marine shores. * E — Sand, shingle or pebble shores. * F — Estuarine waters. * G — Intertidal mud, sand or salt flats. * H — Intertidal marshes. * I — Intertidal forested wetlands. * J — Coastal brackish/saline lagoons. * K — Coastal freshwater lagoons. * Zk(a) - Karst, other subterranean, marine/coastal {{Col-break}} '''Inland Wetlands''' * L — Permanent inland deltas. * M — Permanent rivers/streams/creeks. * N — Intermittent rivers/streams/creeks. * O — Permanent freshwater lakes * P — Intermittent freshwater lakes * Q — Permanent saline/brackish/alkaline lakes * R — Intermittent saline/brackish/alkaline lakes and flats. * Sp - Permanent saline/brackish/alkaline marshes/pools. * Ss - Intermittent saline/brackish/alkaline marshes/pools. * Tp - Permanent freshwater marshes/pools * Ts - Intermittent freshwater marshes/pools on inorganic soils * U — Non-forested peatlands {{Col-break}} * Va - Alpine wetlands * Vt - Tundra wetlands * W — Shrub-dominated wetlands * Xf - Freshwater, tree-dominated wetlands * Xp - Forested peatlands; peatswamp forests. * Y — Freshwater springs; oases. * Zg - Geothermal wetlands * Zk(b)- Karst other subterranean, inland '''Human-Made Wetlands''' * 1 - 9 (Various; See full list) {{col-end}} ==See also== * [[Ramsar Convention]] * [[List of Ramsar wetlands of international importance|List of Ramsar sites worldwide]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.ramsar.org The Ramsar Convention on Wetlands] * [http://www.ramsarcommittee.us United States National Ramsar Committee] __NOTOC__ [[Category:Ramsar sites in Russia| ]] [[Category:Lists of places in Russia]] [[Category:Lists of Ramsar sites|Russia]]

revision.text:
{{see also|List of flora of the Sonoran Desert Region by common name}} The wildflowers of the Sonoran Desert typically appear after a rain, some after the winter rains, and some after the summer "monsoons."
==''[[Amsinckia menziesii]]''== * Common name: common fiddleneck * Flowers bloom March through May <gallery> Image:Amsinckia intermedia 2003-03-04.jpg </gallery>
==''[[Anemone tuberosa]]''== * Common name: [http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=ANTU desert anemone] * Flowers bloom February to April
==''[[Bahia absinthifolia]]''== * Common name: [http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=BAAB hairyseed bahia], silverleaf bahia * Flowers bloom spring through fall
==''[[Brickellia coulteri]]''== * Common name: [http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=BRCO Coulter's brickellbush] * Flowers bloom March to November
==''[[Carlowrightia arizonica]]''== * Common name: [http://plants.usda.gov/java/nameSearch Arizona wrightwort] * Flowers bloom in the spring
==''[[Centaurium calycosum]]''== * Common name: Arizona centaury * Flowers bloom April to June <gallery> Image:Arizona Centaury centaurium calycosum.jpg </gallery>
==''[[Cryptantha albida]]''== * Common name: New Mexico catseye, [http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=CRAL New Mexico cryptantha] * Flowers bloom in early spring
==''[[Cryptantha angustifolia]]''== * Common name: Panamint catseye, bristlelobe cryptantha * Flowers bloom in early spring <gallery> Image:Cryptantha angustifolia.jpg </gallery>
==''[[Daucus pusillus]]''== * Common name: [http://plants.usda.gov/java/nameSearch American wild carrot] * Flowers bloom March to May
==''[[Datura innoxia]]''== * Common name: pricklyburr ==''[[Dichelostemma capitatum]]''== * Common name: bluedicks * Flowers bloom February to May <gallery> Image:Dichelostemma capitatum 1.jpg Image:Dichelostemma capitatum 2.jpg Image:Dichelostemma capitatum 3.jpg Image:Dichelostemma capitatum 4.jpg </gallery>
==''[[Encelia farinosa]]''== * Common name: brittlebush * Flowers bloom in the spring <gallery> Image:Encelia farinosa form.jpg Image:Encelia farinosa var. radians head 2002-10-10.jpg Image:Encelia farinosa on slope 2005-02-20.jpg Image:Encelia farinosa capitulum 2005-02-20.jpg </gallery>
==''[[Eriophyllum lanosum]]''== *Common name: white woolly daisy * Flowers bloom February through May
==''[[Galium aparine]]''== * Common name: common bedstraw, cleavers, stickywilly * Flowers bloom in the spring <gallery> Image:Galium aparine01.jpg Image:Galium.aparine.jpg Image:Galium aparine001.JPG </gallery>
==''[[Geraea canescens]]''== * Common name: desert sunflower, hairy desert sunflower, desert gold <gallery> Image:Geraea canescens form 2.jpg Image:Geraea canescens form 1.jpg Image:Geraea canescens flower.jpg Image:Geraea canescens 2005-02-20.jpg </gallery>
==''[[Glandularia gooddingii]]''== * Common name: Gooding's verbena, [http://plants.usda.gov/java/ClassificationServlet?source=profile&symbol=GLGO&display=31 southwestern mock vervain] * Flowers bloom winter, spring, and fall
==''[[Haplophyton crooksii]]''== * Common name: cockroachplant * Flowers bloom March to April and July to November
==''[[Isocoma tenuisecta]]''== * Common name: burroweed, shrine jimmyweed, burrow goldenweed * Flowers bloom in September through November <gallery> Image:Isocoma tenuisecta.jpg Image:Isocoma tenuisecta2.jpg Image:Isocoma tenuisecta3.jpg </gallery>
==''[[Justicia californica]]''== * Common name: beloperone, chuparosa * Flowers bloom in the spring <gallery> Image:Justicia californica 3.jpg Image:Justicia californica 1.jpg </gallery>
==''[[Machaeranthera gracilis]]''== * Common name: slender goldenweed, yellow spiny daisy * Flowers bloom February to December
==''[[Malacothrix californica]]''== * Common name: California desertdandelion
==''[[Marina parryi]]''== * Common name: Parry's false prairie-clover
==''[[Melampodium leucanthum]]''== * Common name: plains blackfoot, blackfoot daisy * Flowers bloom March through December <gallery> Image:Melampodium-leucanthum.jpg </gallery>
==''[[Monoptilon bellioides]]''== * Common name: Mojave desert star
==''[[Nama demissum]]''== * Common name: purplemat * Flowers bloom from February to May <gallery> Image:Nama demissum 6.jpg Image:Nama demissum 3.jpg Image:Nama demissum 4.jpg Image:Nama demissum 5.jpg </gallery>
==''[[Nicotiana obtusifolia]]''== * Common name: desert tobacco, coyote tobacco * Flowers bloom spring to fall <gallery> Image:Nicotiana obtusifolia.jpg Image:Nicotiana obtusifolia form.jpg Image:Nicotiana obtusifolia flower.jpg </gallery>
==''[[Penstemon parryi]]''== * Common name: Parry's penstemon * Flowers bloom February to April <gallery> Image:Parry's Penstemon- Penstemon parryi.JPG </gallery>
==''[[Physaria purpurea]]''== * Common name: rose bladderpod * Flowers bloom January to May
==''[[Proboscidea parviflora]]''== * Common name: doubleclaw
==''[[Rafinesquia neomexicana]]''== * Common name: desert chicory, New Mexico plumeseed * Flowers bloom mid-February to May <gallery> Image:Rafinesquia neomexicana 2.jpg Image:Rafinesquia neomexicana 1.jpg Image:Rafinesquia neomexicana capitulum 2005-04-01.jpg </gallery>
==''[[Salvia columbariae]]''== * Common name: chia * Flowers bloom March–May <gallery> Image:Salvia columbariae 3.jpg Image:Salvia columbariae 2.jpg Image:Salvia columbariae 1.jpg Image:Salvia columbariae 2003-04-11.jpg </gallery>
==''[[Senna covesii]]''== * Common name: Coues' senna * Flowers bloom in spring and fall <gallery> Image:Desertsenna.JPG Image:Senna covesii.jpg </gallery>
==''[[Senna wislizeni]]''== * Common name: Wislizenus' senna, shrubby senna * Flowers bloom in the mid to late summer
==''[[Silene antirrhina]]''== * Common name: sleepy catchfly, [http://plants.usda.gov/java/nameSearch sleepy silene] * Flowers bloom March to August
==''[[Sphaeralcea ambigua]]''== * Common name: desert globemallow, apricot mallow * Flowers bloom in the spring <gallery> Image:Sphaeralcea ambigua 4.jpg Image:Sphaeralcea ambigua 2.jpg Image:Sphaeralcea ambigua 1.jpg </gallery>
==''[[Trixis californica]]''== * Common name: American threefold * Flowers after rains, most commonly in the spring <gallery> Image:Trixis californica flower 2.jpg Image:Trixis californica form.jpg Image:Trixis californica flower 1.jpg </gallery>
==See also== {{Commonscat|Flora of the Sonoran Desert}} * [[List of flora of the Sonoran Desert Region by common name]] * [[:Category:Flora of the Sonoran Deserts|Index: Flora of the Sonoran Deserts]] * [[List of southern LCRV flora by region]] — ''Lower Colorado River Valley''.
==References== {{Reflist}} * [http://www.desertmuseum.org/center/swbiodiversity.php Arizona—Sonora Desert Museum: Flora of the Sonoran Desert Region] * [http://uswildflowers.com/stateref.php?State=AZ U.S. Wildflowers Reference List: Arizona] — ''Reference List of websites for Arizona Wildflower Identification''. * [http://wc.pima.edu/~bfiero/tucsonecology/plants/wflowers.htm Pima Community College. Common Wildflowers of Tucson.] * [http://www.aznps.com/floras.php Floras - Arizona Native Plant Society] * [http://plants.usda.gov/index.html USDA Plants Database] — ''plant profiles search engine, by common or botanical names, or by U.S. state''.
==External links== *[http://www.desertmuseum.org/programs/flw_flowering.php Arizona—Sonora Desert Museum: Desert Wildflower Blooms] — ''homepage, with focus article links''. *[http://www.desertmuseum.org/programs/flw_desertbloom.php Arizona—Sonora Desert Museum: The Desert in Bloom] *[http://www.art-botanical.org/IllustrationsIntro.html Sonoran Desert Florilegium Program] — ''homepage: botanical illustrations.'' *[http://www.desertusa.com/wildflo/FieldGuide/fieldguide.html Desert USA: Desert Wildflower Field Guide] — ''Wildflower pictures sorted by Color''.

This is a list of notable '''environmental reports'''. In this context they relate to the impacts of human activity on the [[environment (biophysical)|environment]].
*[[City-level Decoupling: Urban Resource Flows and the Governance of Infrastructure Transitions]] – by the [[International Resource Panel]] *[[Clean Energy Trends]] – a series of reports by Clean Edge – beginning in 2002 *[[Copeland Report]] – for the U.S. government, completed in 1933 *[[Copenhagen Diagnosis]] – written by twenty-six climate scientists from eight countries *[[Dioxin Reassessment Report]] – by the United States Environmental Protection Agency *[[Environmental Impact of the Big Cypress Swamp Jetport]] ("Leopold Report") – [[United States Department of the Interior]] (1969) *[[Environmental Risks and Challenges of Anthropogenic Metals Flows and Cycles]] – by the [[International Resource Panel]] *[[Forest Principles]] – United Nations Conference on Environment and Development (UNCED) *''[[The Global 2000 Report to the President]]'' – Council on Environmental Quality (1981) *[[Global Environment Outlook]] – United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) *[[Hirsch report]] (''Peaking of World Oil Production: Impacts, Mitigation, and Risk Management'') – United States Department of Energy *''[[Index of Leading Environmental Indicators]]'' – Pacific Research Institute *[[IPCC First Assessment Report]] – Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) *[[IPCC supplementary report, 1992]] – IPCC *[[IPCC Second Assessment Report]] – IPCC *[[IPCC Third Assessment Report]] ''Climate Change 2001'' – IPCC (2001) *[[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]] ''Climate Change 2007'' – IPCC (2007) *[[IPCC Fifth Assessment Report]] (2014) *[[Leopold Report]] ("Wildlife Management in the National Parks") – Special Advisory Board on Wildlife Management (1963) *''[[Livestock's Long Shadow|Livestock's Long Shadow – Environmental Issues and Options]]'' – United Nations (2006) *''[[Living Planet Report]]'' – WWF, every two years *''[[Making Sweden an Oil-Free Society]]'' – Government of Sweden (2006) *''[[Meat Atlas]]'' – published by the [[Heinrich Böll Foundation]] and [[Friends of the Earth Europe]] *''[[Nuclear Power and the Environment]]'' – UK [[Royal Commission on Environmental Pollution]] – 1976 *''[[Our Common Future]]'' – World Commission on Environment and Development (1987) *''[[Outlook On Renewable Energy In America]]'' (2 volumes) – [[American Council on Renewable Energy]] – 2007 *[[Phase I Environmental Site Assessment]] – generic *''[http://www.thelancet.com/commissions/pollution-and-health/ Pollution and Health (Lancet Commission Report on Pollution and Health 2017]'' *''[[PPS 10|Planning Policy Statement 10: Planning for Sustainable Waste Management]]'' (PPS 10) – British Government *''[[Renewable Energy Sources and Climate Change Mitigation]]'' – [[United Nations]] [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] (IPCC) – planned for 2010 *''[[Report of the Royal Commission on Genetic Modification]]'' – Royal Commission on Genetic Modification (2001) *''[[State of the Climate]]'' – NOAA/NCDC (published annually) *''[[State of the World (book series)|The State of the World]]'' – Worldwatch Institute (published yearly since 1984) *''[https://cfpub.epa.gov/roe/ US Environmental Protection Agency – Report on the Environment]'' – US EPA (2016) *''[[Wegman Report]]'' – to validate criticisms of reconstructions of the [[temperature record of the past 1000 years]] *''[[Windscale: Britain’s Biggest Nuclear Disaster]]'' (2007) *''[[World Climate Report]]'' – Greening Earth Society *''[[The World's 25 Most Endangered Primates]]'' – selected and published by the IUCN Species Survival Commission Primate Specialist Group (IUCN/SSC PSG), the International Primatological Society (IPS), and Conservation International (CI)
==See also== *[[Why the future doesn't need us]] – Bill Joy – April 2000 issue of Wired magazine *[[2008 Climatic Research Unit study]] *[[Garnaut Climate Change Review]] *[[Global Environment Outlook]] *[[Green annual report]] *[[List of environmental books]] *[[List of environmental law reviews and journals]] *[[List of environmental periodicals]] *[[List of environmental websites]] *[[Lists of environmental publications]] *[[State of the Environment]]
[[Category:Lists of environmental topics|Reports]]

page.title: List of national parks of Norway

revision.comment: Replacing Hallingskarvet.jpg with [[File:Eastern_part_of_Hallingskarvet.jpg]] (by [[commons:User:CommonsDelinker|CommonsDelinker]] because: [[:c:COM:FR|File renamed]]: #2 not the whole, but eastern).
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} [[File:Norske nasjonalparker kart.jpg|thumb|Map of mainland national parks in 2018]] [[File:Svalbard protected areas map with names.svg|thumb|National parks (green), nature reserves (purple), geotope protection areas (orange) and bird sanctuaries of Svalbard]] [[Norway]] has 47 [[national park]]s, of which 37 are on the mainland and 7 on [[Svalbard]]. National parks in Norway are stricter than many other countries, and nearly all motorized vehicles are prohibited. The [[freedom to roam]] applies, thus hiking, skiing and camping throughout the park are permitted, given that consideration to nature is taken. Roads, accommodation and national park centers are located outside the national parks. The parks are under the management of the [[Norwegian Directorate for Nature Management]] and the local [[county governor (Norway)|county governor]].{{cite web |url=http://english.dirnat.no/multimedia/48381/Kart-og-informasjon-eng.pdf |title=Maps and information |publisher=[[Norwegian Directorate for Nature Management]] |format=PDF |accessdate=21 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926234128/http://english.dirnat.no/multimedia/48381/Kart-og-informasjon-eng.pdf |archivedate=26 September 2011 |df=dmy-all }} [[Ytre Hvaler National Park|Ytre Hvaler]] is a [[marine park]] and all parks in Svalbard also contain marine areas. [[Sør-Spitsbergen National Park|Sør-Spitsbergen]] is the largest park, covering an area of {{convert|13286|km2|abbr=on}}, although only {{convert|5141|km2|abbr=on}} is land.{{cite web |url=http://www.dirnat.no/attachment.ap?id=1043 |title=Protected Areas in Svalbard |publisher=[[Norwegian Directorate for Nature Management]] |accessdate=14 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65uFT8vgO?url=http://www.dirnat.no/attachment.ap?id=1043 |archivedate=4 March 2012 |df= }} The largest park on the mainland is [[Hardangervidda National Park|Hardangervidda]], which covers an area of {{convert|3422|km2|abbr=on}}. [[Gutulia National Park|Gutulia]] is the smallest, covering {{convert|23|km2|abbr=on}}. == Geography and history == At least 60% of Norway's area is mountainous, lakes or bogs (non-arable land, some of it is used as pastures); 37% is forest of various kinds; and only 3% arable land. It is estimated that between 1900 and 2003 areas more than 5 km from intense construction activity has decreased from 48% to 12% in Norway. Until about one hundred years ago there was relatively little threat to ecosystems in Norway. The first initiatives to protect land were voiced in 1904, by [[Yngvar Nielsen]], leader of the [[Norwegian Mountain Touring Association]] (DNT). The association continued to lobby cases in 1923 and 1938. The natural protection act of 1954 prepared a legal basis for establishing protection areas, and the two first national parks were established in 1962 and 1963. The act of 1954 also established ''Statens naturvernråd'' ("''Governmental Natural protection council''") as an advisory body for the government. The council presented a draft for further natural protecting in 1964, suggesting 16 national parks. These suggestions were approved by [[Stortinget]]. It took 25 years, until 1989, before 15 of their suggestions were fulfilled. The 16th suggestion became a ''naturreservat''. The council presented another suggestion in 1986,Ny landsplan for nasjonalparker / fra en arbeidsgruppe oppnevnt 3. September 1982 ; utredningen avgitt til Miljøverndepartementet April 1986. Oslo, 1986 (Norges offentlige utredninger ; NOU 1986: 13). {{ISBN|82-00-71038-6}} and this was approved by Stortinget in April 1993. Following this approval, a "second generation" of national parks, as well as expanding borders for the elder, were established from 2001. The post-industrial era that started in the last 1960s saw areas being protected as national parks or other protected status as a means to regulate the construction of vacation homes, roads, fishing, hunting, and gathering plants. This trend has accelerated in the last 10 years. In addition to preserving rare plant and animal life, areas are protected to maintain reference points for environmental research, recreational resources for Norwegians, and as an inheritance for future generations. The [[Norwegian Directorate for Nature Management|Directorate for Nature Management]] maintains indicators for the health of nature in Norway, including such measures as biological diversity, erosion, signs of pollution. For the most part, national parks are open to hiking, cross-country skiing and camping. Most have a limited number of overnight cabins. In addition to national parks, the Norwegian government has designated larger areas for protection. Included in these areas are 153 landscapes covering 14071 km2; 1,701 nature reserves covering 3,418 km2; 24 national parks covering 21,650 km2; 102 natural memorials, and 98 smaller protected areas. This accounts for 12.1% of Norway's mainland area. The Norwegian government aims to increase this area over time to at least 15%. They have signalled an interest in preserving marine ecosystems, including the [[fjord]]s of the western parts of Norway, and the archipelago southwest from [[Oslo]]. {{clear}} ==Current== {|class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" ! scope=col class=unsortable | Image ! scope=col | Name ! scope=col | County(s) ! scope=col | Est. ! scope=col | Area ! scope=col class=unsortable | Description ! scope=col class=unsortable | Ref |- | [[File:Auroral-band-over-Senja.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | {{sort|Anderdalen|[[Ånderdalen National Park|Ånderdalen]]}} | [[Troms]] | 1970 | {{convert|125|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | align=center | — ! scope=row | [[Blåfjella–Skjækerfjella National Park|Blåfjella–Skjækerfjella]] | [[Nord-Trøndelag]] | 2004 | {{convert|1924|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:P1000154Gamle Strynefjellsvegen.JPG|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Breheimen National Park|Breheimen]] | [[Oppland]], [[Sogn og Fjordane]] | 2009 | {{convert|1671|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | |- | [[File:VM.JPG|150px]] ! scope=row | {{sort|Borgefjell|[[Børgefjell National Park|Børgefjell]]}} | [[Nord-Trøndelag]], [[Nordland]] | 1963 | {{convert|1447|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:Grimsdalen Panorama4718.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Dovre National Park|Dovre]] | [[Oppland]] | 2003 | {{convert|289|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:Dovrefjell.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Dovrefjell–Sunndalsfjella National Park|Dovrefjell–Sunndalsfjella]] | [[Møre og Romsdal]], [[Oppland]], [[Sør-Trøndelag]] | 1974 | {{convert|1693|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:Færder.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Færder National Park|Færder]] | [[Vestfold]] | 2013 | {{convert|350|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:Engerdal Femunden.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Femundsmarka National Park|Femundsmarka]] | [[Hedmark]], [[Sør-Trøndelag]] | 1971 | {{convert|573|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:Lake Bondhus Norway 2862.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Folgefonna National Park|Folgefonna]] | [[Hordaland]] | 2005 | {{convert|545|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:Morsy1 (js).jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Forlandet National Park|Forlandet]] | [[Svalbard]] | 1973 | {{convert|4647|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | The park covers the uninhabited island of [[Prins Karls Forland]] and the surrounding waters. Forlandet is long and narrow with tall peaks, separated in two by the low [[Forlandsletta]]. It is the northern-most habitat of [[harbor seal]] and a nesting place for [[common guillemot]]. Wetland birds nest at [[Plankeholmane Bird Sanctuary|Plankeholmane]] and [[Forlandsøyane Bird Sanctuary|Forlandsøyane]], and the west coast is an overwintering site for seabirds. | align=center | |- | [[File:ForollhognaView.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Forollhogna National Park|Forollhogna]] | [[Sør-Trøndelag]], [[Hedmark]] | 2001 | {{convert|1062|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | align=center | [[File:Fulufjellet nasjonalpark 007.JPG|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Fulufjellet National Park|Fulufjellet]] | [[Hedmark]] | 2012 | {{convert|83|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | {{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Fulufjellet nasjonalpark er oppretta | work = | publisher = Miljøverndepartementet | date = | url = http://www.regjeringen.no/nb/dep/md/pressesenter/pressemeldinger/2012/fulufjellet-nasjonalpark-er-oppretta.html?id=680146 | format = Norwegian | doi = | accessdate = 22 May 2012 }} |- | [[File:Gutulia 08-0003.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Gutulia National Park|Gutulia]] | [[Hedmark]] | 1968 | {{convert|23|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:Eastern part of Hallingskarvet.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Hallingskarvet National Park|Hallingskarvet]] | [[Buskerud]], [[Hordaland]] | 2006 | {{convert|450|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | |- | [[File:Hardangervidda 1986.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Hardangervidda National Park|Hardangervidda]] | [[Buskerud]], [[Hordaland]], [[Telemark]] | 1981 | {{convert|3422|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | align=center | [[File:Indre Wijdefjorden National Park map.svg|150x150px]] ! scope=row | [[Indre Wijdefjorden National Park|Indre Wijdefjorden]] | [[Svalbard]] | 2005 | {{convert|1127|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | Located in a steep [[fjord]] landscape in northern [[Spitsbergen]], the park covers the inner part of [[Wijdefjorden]]—the longest fjord on Svalbard. On both sides of Wijdefjorden there is High Arctic [[steppe]] vegetation, dominated by grasses and extremely dry, [[base (chemistry)|basic]] earth. Along with vegetation found on nesting cliffs, it is the most exclusive flora in Svalbard. Of the larger fjords on Svalbard, Wijdefjorden is the least affected by humans. | align=center | |- | [[File:Briksdalsbreen.JPG|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Jostedalsbreen National Park|Jostedalsbreen]] | [[Sogn og Fjordane]] | 1991 | {{convert|1310|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:Jotunheimen - view from Galdhøpiggen.JPG|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Jotunheimen National Park|Jotunheimen]] | [[Oppland]], [[Sogn og Fjordane]] | 1980 | {{convert|1151|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:Sjurfjellet.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Junkerdal National Park|Junkerdal]] | [[Nordland]] | 2004 | {{convert|682|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:Utsikt mot Lahku nasjonalpark fra Skavldalen.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Làhku National Park|Làhku]] | [[Nordland]] | 2012 | {{convert|188|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} |- | [[File:Røssjøkollbua.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Langsua National Park|Langsua]] | [[Oppland]] | 2011 | {{convert|537|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} |- | align=center | — ! scope=row | [[Lierne National Park|Lierne]] | [[Nordland]] | 2004 | {{convert|333|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:Lomsdalen.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Lomsdal–Visten National Park|Lomsdal–Visten]] | [[Nordland]] | 2009 | {{convert|682|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | |- | [[File:Moysalen 2.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Møysalen National Park|Møysalen]] | [[Nordland]] | 2003 | {{convert|51|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} |- | [[File:Tundra1 (js).jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Nordenskiöld Land National Park|Nordenskiöld Land]] | [[Svalbard]] | 2003 | {{convert|1362|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | The park covers the southern part of [[Nordenskiöld Land]], on the north shore of [[Van Mijenfjorden]]. [[Reindalen]] is Svalbard's largest ice-free valley and features [[moraine]]s, [[rock glacier]]s, [[pingo]]s and [[avalanche]] features. The valley has a luch vegetation and the lower part is a [[wetland]]. The area is important for [[reindeer]], [[Arctic fox]], [[wader]]s, [[geese]] and [[duck]]s. | align=center | |- | [[File:Daudmannsodden Lexfjellet IMG 2538.JPG|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Nordre Isfjorden National Park|Nordre Isfjorden]] | [[Svalbard]] | 2003 | {{convert|2954|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | Protecting the northern shore of [[Isfjorden (Svalbard)|Isfjorden]] on [[Spitsbergen]], the park consists of a long shore-line with lush vegetation serving as breeding grounds for birds. The landscape varies from the barren and lunar-like to sandy plains and several meter-thick layers of deposits. | align=center | |- | [[File:Lilliehookbreen1.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Nordvest-Spitsbergen National Park|Nordvest-Spitsbergen]] | [[Svalbard]] | 1973 | {{convert|9914|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | The northwestern part of [[Spitsbergen]] has the archipelago's most varied nature and features some of the most important cultural heritage sites from [[whaling]] and [[Arctic exploration]], such as [[Smeerenburg]] and [[Virgohamna]]. The park is habitat for [[Arctic fox]], [[reindeer]] and [[Arctic char]]. [[Moffen Nature Reserve]] and three [[bird sanctuaries]] ([[Guissezholmen Bird Sanctuary|Guissezholmen]], [[Moseøya Bird Sanctuary|Moseøya]] and [[Skorpa Bird Sanctuary|Skorpa]]) are important breeding grounds for birds, especially [[eider]] and [[geese]]. The warm springs of [[Bockfjorden]] give a unique local flora. | align=center | |- | [[File:Arctic sunset.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | {{sort|Ovre Anarjohka|[[Øvre Anárjohka National Park|Øvre Anárjohka]]}} | [[Finnmark]] | 1975 | {{convert|1390|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:Övre dividal anjajohka.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | {{sort|Ovre Dividal|[[Øvre Dividal National Park|Øvre Dividal]]}} | [[Troms]] | 1971 | {{convert|750|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:Russia-Norway-Finland border.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | {{sort|Ovre Pasvik|[[Øvre Pasvik National Park|Øvre Pasvik]]}} | [[Finnmark]] | 1970 | {{convert|119|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | Part of [[Pasvik–Inari Trilateral Park]], the area is dominated by [[Siberia]]n-like [[taiga]] consisting of [[old-growth]] [[Scots pine]], shallow lakes and [[bog]]. The traditional [[Skolts]] area is still used for [[reindeer husbandry]]. The park located in [[Pasvikdalen]] and is a habitat for [[brown bear]] and [[moose]]. | align=center | {{cite web |url=http://www.dirnat.no/attachment.ap?id=2109 |title=Øvre Pasvik nasjonalpark |publisher=[[Norwegian Directorate for Nature Management]] |format=PDF |language=Norwegian |accessdate=24 August 2012 |archivedate=24 August 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6A9pYHMNR?url=http://www.dirnat.no/attachment.ap?id=2109 |deadurl=yes |df= }} |- | [[File:Rago001.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Rago National Park|Rago]] | [[Nordland]] | 1971 | {{convert|171|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:Karitinden.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Reinheimen National Park|Reinheimen]] | [[Oppland]], [[Møre og Romsdal]] | 2006 | {{convert|1969|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | |- | align=center | [[File:Mollisfossen.jpg|150x150px]] ! scope=row | [[Reisa National Park|Reisa]] | [[Troms]] | 1986 | {{convert|803|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:Canyon in Rohkunborri National Park.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Rohkunborri National Park|Rohkunborri]] | [[Troms]] | 2011 | {{convert|571|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | |- | [[File:Rondane haust.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Rondane National Park|Rondane]] | [[Hedmark]], [[Oppland]] | 1962 | {{convert|963|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:Bjellåvasstua.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Saltfjellet–Svartisen National Park|Saltfjellet–Svartisen]] | [[Nordland]] | 1989 | {{convert|2102|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:Sassenfjorden.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Sassen–Bünsow Land National Park|Sassen–Bünsow Land]] | [[Svalbard]] | 2003 | {{convert|1230|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | The park covers [[Tempelfjorden]], [[Bünsow Land]] and the vast [[fluvial]] [[plain]] of [[Sassendalen]], located at the head of [[Isfjorden (Svalbard)|Isfjorden]]. Tempelfjorden is an important breeding ground for [[ringed seal]]s, while Sassendalen and [[Gipsdalen]] are important breeding grounds for [[geese]]. Bünsow Land has the only European occurrence of [[polar mouse-ear]] and [[saxifraga platysepala|broad-sepal saxifrage]]. | align=center | |- | [[File:Seiland2b.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Seiland National Park|Seiland]] | [[Finnmark]] | 2006 | {{convert|316|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | |- | [[File:Towards Sjunkhatten National Park.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Sjunkhatten National Park|Sjunkhatten]] | [[Nordland]] | 2010 | {{convert|417|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | |- | [[File:Skarvan 1.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Skarvan and Roltdalen National Park|Skarvan and Roltdalen]] | [[Nord-Trøndelag]], [[Sør-Trøndelag]] | 2004 | {{convert|441|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:Polar Bear (js) 2.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | {{sort|Sor-Spitsbergen|[[Sør-Spitsbergen National Park|Sør-Spitsbergen]]}} | [[Svalbard]] | 1973 | {{convert|13286|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | Covering the southern part of [[Spitsbergen]] ([[Wedel Jarlsberg Land]], [[Torell Land]] and [[Sørkapp Land]]), the western part has jagged mountains while the eastern part is more rounded. [[Hornsund]] is an important migration area for [[polar bear]]s, while four [[bird sanctuaries]] ([[Olsholmen Bird Sanctuary|Olsholmen]], [[Isøyane Bird Sanctuary|Isøyane]], [[Dunøyane Bird Sanctuary|Dunøyane]] and [[Sørkapp Bird Sanctuary|Sørkapp]]) are vital nesting grounds for migratory seabirds. | align=center | |- | ! scope=row | [[Stabbursdalen National Park|Stabbursdalen]] | [[Finnmark]] | 1970 | {{convert|747|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:E75-Varanger-Vardø-2012-07-07-16-30-03.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Varangerhalvøya National Park|Varangerhalvøya]] | [[Finnmark]] | 2006 | {{convert|1804|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:Ytre Hvaler, Landfasten vegetation.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Ytre Hvaler National Park|Ytre Hvaler]] | [[Østfold]] | 2009 | {{convert|354|km2|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | | align=center | |- | [[File:Arendal Tromøy Spornes b.JPG|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Raet National Park|Raet]] | [[Aust-Agder]] | 2016 | | | align=center | |- | [[File:Jomfruland fyrvokterbolig.jpg|150px]] ! scope=row | [[Jomfruland National Park|Jomfruland]] | [[Telemark]] | 2016 | | | align=center | |- | ! scope=row | [[Lofotodden]] | [[Nordland]] | 2018 | | | align=center | |} ==Former== {|class="wikitable sortable" !
